name: Development Workflow
description: Essential development concepts and workflows for software engineers

cards.back: Version control system that tracks code changes over time. Lets you see what changed, when, and by whom. Enables collaboration and rollback to previous versions.
A snapshot of your code at a point in time with a descriptive message. Created with: git add . then git commit -m "Your message". Each commit has a unique ID (SHA hash).

A separate line of development. Lets you work on features without affecting the main code. The 'main' or 'master' branch is typically the stable production code. Create with: git checkout -b feature-name
A request to merge your branch changes into another branch (usually main). Allows code review before merging. Workflow: Create branch -> make changes -> push -> open PR -> get review -> merge.

Occurs when Git can't automatically combine changes because multiple people edited the same lines. Git marks conflicts with <<<<<<< HEAD, =======, and >>>>>>> markers. You must manually resolve by choosing which changes to keep.

npm (Node Package Manager) installs JavaScript libraries. package.json lists your project's dependencies. Commands: 'npm install' gets all listed packages, 'npm install axios' adds a new package and updates package.json.

A tool that analyzes code for errors and style issues without running it. Catches problems like unused variables, missing semicolons, and inconsistent formatting. Examples: ESLint (JS), Pylint (Python), Clippy (Rust).
Code that tests a small, isolated piece of your application. Example: test('adds 1 + 2 to equal 3', () => { expect(add(1, 2)).toBe(3); }). Helps catch bugs early and ensures code works as expected.

The process of finding and fixing bugs in code. Techniques: console.log() to print values, debugger breakpoints to pause execution, reading error messages and stack traces, rubber duck debugging (explaining code aloud).

A list showing the path code execution took to reach an error. Read from bottom to top to trace the call sequence. Shows file names, line numbers, and function names. Essential for debugging crashes and exceptions.

Improving code structure without changing its behavior. Goals: make code easier to read, reduce duplication, improve performance, simplify complexity. Always have tests before refactoring to ensure you don't break anything.
A text interface to control your computer by typing commands. Essential commands: cd (change directory), ls (list files), mkdir (create folder), rm (remove), cat (view file), grep (search text).

Integrated Development Environment - a program for writing code with helpful features. Includes: syntax highlighting, autocomplete, debugging tools, file navigation, integrated terminal. Examples: VS Code, IntelliJ, Xcode.
A file listing patterns of files/folders Git should NOT track. Common entries: node_modules/, .env, *.log, .DS_Store, build/, dist/. Keeps sensitive data and generated files out of version control.

Converting source code into production-ready form. May include: compiling TypeScript to JavaScript, bundling modules, minifying code, optimizing images, generating source maps. Tools: webpack, Vite, esbuild.

Automatically updating your app when you save code, without manual refresh. The dev server watches files, detects changes, and updates the browser instantly. Preserves application state during development.
A file storing environment variables and secrets like API keys and database URLs. Format: KEY=value. Never commit to git! Use .env.example to document required variables without actual values.

Messages your app writes to record what's happening. Levels from most to least verbose: DEBUG, INFO, WARN, ERROR, FATAL. Use structured logging in production. Essential for debugging issues in deployed apps.
Having others examine your code before merging. Reviewers check for: bugs, security issues, code style, performance problems, and design improvements. Helps share knowledge and maintain code quality.
Version numbering format: MAJOR.MINOR.PATCH (e.g., 2.4.1). MAJOR: breaking changes. MINOR: new features, backwards compatible. PATCH: bug fixes. Helps users understand upgrade impact.
